I scrutinised it. I asked my wife how she liked it. She said she liked it very much. I asked the stranger how much he wanted. He said £16—he gave £20 for it. There is a pawnbroker opposite my door and, unbeknown to Mr. Barron or the stranger, I said to my barmaid, "Slip across the road and ask what the ring is worth." She came back and said he could not value it: it was a false light. I asked the stranger if he would leave it with me all night and give me an opportunity to offer him a price. He did. I sent it next morning to another pawnbroker. His manager told my barmaid if I could buy the ring for £10 or £12 it would be a reasonable price. An hour afterwards Barron came in. Know
ing I was going to have it valued, he said, "How did you get on?" I told him what I had done. Barron then suggested we should go and get Birkett's opinion. We went. The ring was in my posses
sion all the time. I asked Birkett to value the ring. The manager said, "Before we value it, it will be 1s." Birkett asked what we had got there, and the manager handed him the ring. Birkett walked to the shop door, pulled out his glass, and scrutinised the ring. Birkett's words were, "It will be 2s. "I said, "It is a funny thing you say 2s. and the man says 1s. What is your charge?" With that Birkett overhauls the rings and says, "I will lend you £6 on this ring." I said, "I never pawned a ring in my life and I am prepared to pay your charge, which is 1s." Birkett said, "This is not the sort of ring for a man like you to wear—a publican." Mr. Barron had never touched that ring all that time. I walked out of the shop and went home. In walks mister stranger. He says, "Have you had my ring valued?" I said, "Yes, there is such a variation in the prices I don't think I will buy it," and I handed him the ring in front of Mr. Barron. They had one or two beverages and as the stranger was going out he said to me, "I will give you another chance." I said, "I have already given you my answer" He left the house with Mr. Barron. On Sunday Mr. Barron walked into my place soon after one o'clock and said he had bought the ring after all. I said, "Well, good luck," something like that." If it is a fair question, what did you give?" He said £7 10s. I felt a bit jealous. He was off my premises by half-past one. On Monday morning Barron total me he had sent the ring to pledge to Mr. Bekett and Mr. Birkett had detained it. He asked me to walk round with him. Before either of us got on his threshold he said, "Come this afternoon about three." I said to Barron, "You can tee the man is busy." Later on Barron's daughter, I think it was, came with a message from Mr. Barron. I went to Birkett's and saw the constable going down to the door. When I went in Birkett says to Blake, "Off my premises." He said also, You and your confede
rate will hear from me." I said, "Thank you: I don't trust you one word or syllable." The commotion was over. We got Blake.

out. Birkett demands Barron's name and address, then mine. I gave my card to the constable and said, "Did you hear what he called me?" He said "Yes. He called you a confederate," and I asked him to take Birkett's name. Verdict,
Not guilty. '
BEFORE JUDGE RENTOUL.
(Friday, September 10.)

p.rs:
, obtaining by false pretences from
George Simpson 9s. 6d., from
William Henry Hobbs 10s. 6d. and from
George Henry Clarke 8s., in each case with intent to defraud.

div1.p: Mr. Morrow prosecuted.

GEORGE SIMPSON ,41, Barking Road, refreshment-room keeper. Prisoner called on me on May 17 last. He was canvassing on behalf of the West Ham United Football Club and asked me if I would care to advertise in his fixture list. That is a well-known football club. He showed me a skeleton fixture list with the different columns blank and with the different people who had already taken space. He said he would give me first preference and told me the different prices. I chose the bottom one on the right-hand corner, which he said would be 9s. 6d. I gave him 10s. in gold. He gave at the change and the receipt. I identify the column I chose. It is a recognised list issued every year. He promised me a proof. Relying on his representation that he was representing the West Ham United Football Company and that this almanac was con
nected with them I parted with my money. I received no proof. I went to the address given on the receipt and found it empty. He had gone away owing rent. I made inquiries and found he was living in Studley Road, Forest Gate. I called there. His wife told me he was not at home. I said I had two young fellows who wanted to advertise in the fixture list. She said he would call on me. He called and wanted to know about those two young fellows, where they lived, and their names. I told him it would be a job to find them as they were in different businesses. I said I would find out and let him know. I said, "What about the fixture list; will it soon be ready?" He said, "Yes, in about three weeks. I am going to collect the matter to send to the printers." I heard nothing more until I saw the fixture list of the West Ham United, and my name was missing.

Cross-examined. I had a West Ham United fixture list in my shop, and you told me you were going to produce one exactly the same art he one you showed me. I was not told that you did not represent any club whatever and that it was a private enterprise of your own. I understand the West Ham United gave out their print
contract; I was not aware who the printing contractor was. I took you to be a genuine concern.

Miss RIDLEY, 445, Catherine Road, Forest Gate. In May last I was in the employ of Mr. Simpson. I remember prisoner calling He said he came on behalf of the West Ham United Football Club He used those words. I was scrubbing in the shop at the time. I did not see what he produced. There was hanging on the wall of the restaurant at the time a copy of the previous year's almanac, Mr. Simpson pointed to it, saying, "Will it be the same as this one? Prisoner replied "Yes."

Cross-examined. I heard you say you came from the West Ham United Club when I was in the shop. I was doing the seat. You had the almanac on the centre table on the right. There were only two customers there. I was on the next seat to you.

WILLIAM HENRY Honus, 23, Barking Road. On June 28 prisoner called on me to get an advertisement. He said, "I am canvassing on behalf of the West Ham United Football Club." I know that organisation. He said, "Would you like to have your advertisement on their football fixture list? I have two spaces left. I thought I would give you the first chance to have one." I said I would see He came into my shop. I called my brother and told him what prisoner had said. He said, "It will be a good thing, Bill, if it is at the right price." Prisoner had got the lists on the counter in front of him, one was with printed matter representing Woolwich and the other was a kind of skeleton affair with tradesmen's bags and bill heads pinned, barring three spaces, one was for the fixture list and the other two were for advertisements. Prisoner pointed to one of them and said, "That is a very prominent space. Why do not you have that one?" I said, "What is the figure?" He said, "12s. 6d., and this little one in the corner is 5s. You will be entitled to six copies yourself and these lists will be put in prominent positions in public halls and all suchlike in the district." I took the larger advertisement. He said, "Will you pay a deposit?" I said, "Will 2s. 6d. do?" He said "Yes." Then he said, "I will tell you something better than that; if you pay the money down I will give you 1s. discount." I then paid him 11s. 6d. and got a receipt When the West Ham United Football Company's list came out my advertisement did not appear.

Cross-examined. You did not hand me that sheet. You never produced the sheets in my shop. You had a sheet and referred to it as the Woolwich sheet, and it had printed matter on it. I have seen you twice since. You did not ask me how I liked the cricket sheet hanging next door. You said "Good morning," and just referred to the weather. You did not tell me it was your own enter prise or that you were the publisher of it.

GEORGE HENRY CLARKE , 218, High Street North, East Ham Prisoner called upon me on June 28 about 9 p.m. and said, "I am canvassing on behalf of the West Ham United Football fixture list Would you like to advertise?" at the same time showing an almanac It was in pencil. He said there was one advertisement left, three or four were after it, and if I did not decide it would soon be taken up. I asked him the charge. He said 10s. I said, "I do not think

shall have anything to do with it." After a lot of talking he said I said, "No, I shall not entertain it." He said "Pay now "He put the thing so well to me, saying it would be shown in pubic halls and free libraries, and it must increase my trade, that I decided. I paid him 8s. and got a receipt. When the fixture list came out my advertisement did not appear.
Cross-examined. I gave you the order at my office, 51, Green street, Upton Park. There are several public halls and libraries in Upton Park and East Ham.
(Other witnesses gave similar evidence.)

ERNEST KING (secretary, West Ham United Football Club). I do not know prisoner. He has had no connection with our club. He has had no authority to apply for orders for advertisements or to receive any money in respect of them.
Cross-examined. I have never seen you before. We have issued the same kind of list for the last five or six years. We do not give receipts like the one produced.
(Defence.)

Mrs. WEBSTER (prisoner's wife). When Mr. Simpson came to our house he asked if you were in. I said no. He said he was sorry, because he had two more customers for you and they wanted to go on the sheet near where he was. He said, "Does your husband publish this sheet himself?" I said "Yes." He said, "I am given to understand he has nothing to with the West Ham Club. "I said, "Nothing whatever," and he asked me, did I know if my husband had any spaces to let on the sheet. I said I did not know. He said these two people, one an electrical engineer and the other a gas and hot water fitter, wanted spaces. I said when my husband came home.
I would tell him. He said, "I hope he will not let the spaces, as he was very anxious these two friends should go on the sheet.
Cross-examined. This was some time in August, about six weeks before the first match was to be played.

JOHN WEBSTER (prisoner, not on oath). It is with sincere regret that I am standing before you this day. I can honestly say that all the evidence with reference to my representing the West Ham Foot ball Club is entirely false. It is nothing more than a conspiracy against me. This is a private enterprise of my own with reference to cricket and football fixtures. There are my cricket fixtures for this year's cricket clubs. The football ones, if I had been at home until last Saturday week, would have been all distributed like the cricket ones were. On the football one you will see where there is a cross. They are repeat orders. Every one of these people know it is a private enterprise, and nothing to do with the West Ham Club. If I had represented myself as representing the club I could have taken orders that would have filled up fifty sheets. When they asked me I distinctly said "No," and there are two people on that sheet now who were willing to make me a cheque out. They said, "I will give you an order; I will make the cheque out to the West Ham
United Football Club." I could have taken the money, but I never represented the club.

Verdict,
Guilty.
Prisoner confessed to having been convicted at North London Sessions on October 13, 1903, for obtaining money by false pretences and another conviction was proved.

Sentence,
15 months' hard labour.

p.rs:
, obtaining by false pre
tences from
Walter George Lamb one peck of cement, one trowel, one gallon of varnish, one brush, one knife, and one other gallon of varnish, in each case with intent to defraud.

div1.p: Mr. Morrow prosecuted.

WALTER GEORGE LAMB , 17, Imperial Terrace, East Ham, dealer in building materials. On June 7 prisoner came to my shop. He said, "I have a job to do at Jeyes' at Plaistow. Can you help me out with it?" I said, "What is it?" He said he wanted a peck of cement and a trowel. I let him have them, believing he was employed by Jeyes'. He promised to pay for them on the morrow. I have not been paid.
Cross-examined. I knew you before this. You had a man with you when you came for the cement. You said it was for your job. I had offered to employ you.

LACRA ALICE LAMB (wife of last witness). On June 25 prisoner came and said he had come from Jeyes', could I let him have a gallon of varnish, a stopping knife, and a dusting brush? My hus
band was upstairs ill. I gave him the things. He has not paid for I them.
Cross-examined. I should not have given you the things if I had I not known where you came from.

JOSEPH TERTIUS SMITH (manager to Jeyes' Sanitary Compound Company). As far as I know no person employed by my company sent prisoner to prosecutor to get goods. We should not send for them; they would be got out of our stores.
(Defence.)

WILLIAM HARCOURT (prisoner, not on oath). I went to get the cement for a man named Parker, who told me he had a job at this factory. He asked me if I would help him. He wished to get it done that afternoon. He said he would want some cement, about a painful. I suggested going to prosecutor's, as I had arranged to do work for him and thought he would trust me with it. I told prose
cutor it was going to Jeyes' place, and it did go there, and was used. I asked him to lend me a trowel. He said he had not one to lend, but would sell me one. After I had worked two hours Parker said he could not pay me till he had seen the manager and I could

not pay prosecutor. I took his trowel back and as I had another job to do I had the varnish. I did not say I had come from Jeyes', Verdict,
Guilty. Fourteen previous convictions were proved. Sentence,
Six months' hard labour.
BEFORE THE RECORDER.
(Saturday, September 11.)

POLITZ, Theodore Hilton (32, agent)
; obtaining by false pre
tests from the
Royal London Mutual Insurance Company, limited, the several sums of 9d., 1s. 11d., and 9 1/2 d.; falsifying a col
lecting book, the goods of the said company; and feloniously forging, knowing the same to be forged, three several authorities, to wit, as
surance proposals, in each case with intent to defraud.
Mr. George Elliott, K. C., and Mr. Drucquer prosecuted.
ERNEST ALBERT ELDRIDGE. I am superintendent of the company's branch office at 425, Grove Green Road, Leytonstone. Prisoner joined the society as a whole-time agent on September 7, 1907. At that time it was a friendly society and has since been turned into a company. He signed an agreement of service in the limited company on October 19, 1906, by which he agreed to give' his whole time to the society and to obey the instructions of the superintendent and the directors of the society. As a remuneration he was to receive ten times the amount of the first premium and 25 per cent, on all pre
miums collected. The business is confined to life assurance, and the society was established in 1861. His duties were to introduce new business and to collect upon the same. The agents are not appointed to one district, but can go where they like. Every week he rendered an account to my branch office. On January 11 I made an analysis of the business Politz had done from his books. The analysis showed that the new business was costing too much, naturally showing a too large percentage of bad business.
(Monday, September 13.)

ERNEST ALBERT ELDRIDGE , further examined. At my request he made out an account showing the actual amount of arrears, which showed that at that date he was in arrear £8 19s. 4¿d. Upon that sum there was due to him on the 25 per cent, commission basis £2 4s. 10d., of course, assuming that the business was genuine and bona fide. That would leave £6 14s. 6 1/2 d. actually due to the com
pany. At that time we had in hand due to him £2 13s. in addition to the £2 14s. 10d., and he gave me his I O U for the balance of £4" 1s. 6 1/2 d. due from him. At that time I did not know that part

of the new business was not genuine. I look at the proposal form purporting to be signed by Beatrice Hutchinson, dated March 26, in
suring the lives of William Floyd, aged 62 next birthday, the weekly premium being 4d. Beatrice Hutchinson is represented to be his daughter. The form was put forward by the prisoner and I believed it to be a subsisting insurance, there being a report upon the form to this effect, "Having made careful inquiries I believe the above particulars to be true and correct, and therefore recommend the direc
tors to grant the policy in accordance therewith. Premiums will be paid by——." Then it is signed by the agent. At the end of the week prisoner made the usual return of the new business introduced during the week, amongst which this proposal appeared. Upon it prisoner would be entitled to credit himself with 3s. 4d. and he credits himself with 10 times the premium on the sheet. Another proposal purports to be signed by Beatrice Hutchinson effecting in
surance on the life of Martha Floyd, the wife of William, the pre
mium in that case being 3d., prisoner being entitled to 2s. 6d. if the insurance was genuine, making 5s. 10d. for the week. The name of Martha Floyd appears in the list of new business with that of William Floyd, and prisoner signed the following certificate: "I hereby certify that the above mentioned industrial business has been legitimately obtained, that I have received the first premium in each case from the assured, and that this certificate and summary are correct." On the other side of the weekly return there is a list of premiums collected during the week under numbers corresponding with numbers in the collecting book and including the premiums pur
porting to have been paid in respect of William Floyd and Martha Floyd. The collecting book is kept by prisoner and he hands it in each week. At the bottom of the statement of cash received there is a summary and balance struck, in which 25 per cent, of the total premiums collected during the week is credited to prisoner. Besides the insurance of William and Martha Floyd, there was genuine new business during the week to the amount of 1s. 11d., representing several policies, making the total new business 2s. 6d., on which pris
oner would be entitled to 10 times 2s. 6d., equals £1 5s. In crediting himself with that amount prisoner credited himself with 5s. 10d. more than he ought to have done. He also credited himself with 7s. 8d. being 25 per cent, on the total amount of premiums collected. Instead of crediting himself with £112s. 8d. he should only have credited him self with £1 6s. 8d. I handed over to him 1s. 11d., which was appa
rently due to him.

To the Jury. None of these forms are signed by the inspector, who is supposed to be a check on the collector. The inspector only signs those forms as to which it is thought necessary to make in
quiry.

Witness proceeded to give evidence as to a proposal form in the names of Henry Roberts and Martha Roberts, purporting to be signed by Ada Robinson, their daughter, of 18, Bolton Road, Plais tow, on April 2, the premiums in each case being 3d. The names

of the two Roberts appeared in the weekly list and the premiums were entered in the collecting book. The amount collected for the week ending April 10 was £1 13s. 11 1/2 d., and all the business was genuine excepting that relating to the two Roberts. Prisoner credited himself with 5s. in respect of the Roberts' policy, and instead of crediting himself as he did with £1 6s. 3d. he should only gave credited himself with £1 1s. 3d. Another fictitious proposal was one signed by Emily Raggett upon the life of her child Arthur R Raggett, aged eight, the premium being 1d. weekly, dated Feb
ruary 24. The proposal appeared in the list of new business for the week ending February 27, and the payment was included in the cash return. In that week prisoner credited himself with new busi
ness and commission amounting to £1 8s. 4d.; deducting the 10 weekly payments of 1d., the amount should have been £1 7s. 6d. Prisoner average earnings were £1 18s. 10d. during the two years he was in the service. The sums of 9d. and 9 1/2 d. were paid to prisoner a balances apparently due to him. The company employs 2,000 agents.

Prisoner here stated that the 10 weeks' premium advanced by the company would have to be refunded if the premiums were not paid. The Recorder. How can you justify placing before your em
ployers a false proposal knowing it to be false? Prisoner replied that it was a common occurrence in this kind of insurance business.
The Recorder. I understand you now to say you admit this was false proposal, and you did it because other people do it.
Prisoner. I had no idea of defrauding the society. I have never done inch a thing in my life.
The Recorder. But you did defraud them of these sums.
Prisoner. That would have been all paid back out of my own pocket.

The Recorder. That is no answer in law. A servant must not falsify his account between himself and his employer and get money as is not entitled to and then say, "I never intended to defraud; I was going to pay it back again."
Prisoner. I did not look at it in that light; it is such a common thing.

The Recorder said that in his opinion there was no defence to this case. Business could not be carried on if commission agents could deliberately put before their employers false statements of amount.

p.rs: On the advice of the Recorder, prisoner with drew his plea and pleaded guilty.

div1.p:
The Jury accordingly found him guilty, and expressed the opinion that the method of doing business was a very lax one, in which ex
pression the Recorder concurred.

Mr. Elliott said the system had been in operation in this com
pany for over half a century, and was the same as that adopted by the "Prudential," one of the largest industrial organisations of the kind, and in that case he believed it had worked satisfactorily. As

prisoner had said, he would have had to repay the premiums ad
vanced to him if they were not subsequently paid.

The Recorder said in his opinion Here had been great laxity in this case, but nothing could justify a commission agent in inventing claims, getting the commission that they represented and putting it into his pocket.

Sentence,
Seven days' imprisonment, entitling prisoner, who has borne a good character, to be discharged.
BEFORE THE COMMON SERJEANT.
(Monday, September 13.)

p.rs:
; between August 26 and 27, 1909, stealing one mare, the goods of
Frederick Joseph Atwell. Mr. Eustace Fulton prosecuted.

div1.p: FREDERICK JOSEPH ATWELL , 65, Roberts Road, Walthamstow, van manager. On August 26, 1909, between 6 and 7 p.m., I saw my blue roan mare at grass in a field by Folly Lane. The next morning I found it had gone, and the following day, Saturday, I went to Crossey's stable, at Holloway, and found the mare. Its value is £5 10s.

PATRICK CROSSEY , 59, Wellington Road, Barnsbury, horse dealer On August 27, at 2 p.m., I was in Islington Cattle Market, when prisoner came to me with the blue roan mare identified by the prose
cutor and said, "I have got a knocker to sell you." I said, "How much do you want for it?" He said, "£4." I said, "Not worth it she is only worth £3 for to kill." After some discussion he agreed to sell it for £3. I then said, "I do not know you—who knows you?" He said, "I am known by everyone." I said, "Before I pay you I want to know someone who knows you." He then took me to the man at the gate of the Cattle Market who passes horses in and clips the tickets, and he stated that he knew the prisoner. I then paid prisoner the £3. The mare was put in my stable and identified by Atwell the following day.

Detective THOMAS CASTLETON, N Division, stationed at Waltham stow. On August 30, at 10 a.m., I saw prisoner and told him I was a police officer and should arrest him for stealing a blue roan mare on the previous Friday morning from a field at Folly Lane, which he had sold to Crossey for £3. He said, "You have made a mistake. "I said, "Well, I shall take you to the station, where you will he put up for identification." He then said, "Well, look here; I will tell you the truth. I was down at Chingford on Thursday, when I met a gipsy, who said that he had an old mare he could do nothing with. He took me to a field in Folly Lane, showed it me, and said, 'There she is, the old cow. His house-van was in the corner of the field We arranged for me to meet him at 3.30 the following morning.

got up, but I was a bit late when I met him, and he gave me the mare and followed me up the road all the way to the market. He said he knew a buyer, but would not deal with him, but a man named Stumpy found the buyer, which was Irish Pat, and he had half a quid for finding him. I paid Stumpy his half a quid in the Pocock Arms. I took the 50 bob to the gipsy, who was waiting outside, and he gave me a dollar back." At the police court prisoner said, "It took me three hours to get up the road."
(Defence.)

JOSEPH EDWARD JACKSON (prisoner, on oath). On August 26 I met a man, whom I had been in company with several time. He told me he had an old mare which he would be glad to get rid of, as he could do nothing with her. I told him I would meet him next morn
ing on the road at three o'clock. I did not meet him till 20 minutes to six—the mare was feeding on the waste ground on the road side. He gave her over to me and walked by my side to the Caledonian Road Cattle Market, where he said "he knew a buyer who, he said, would not buy anything from him. He then left me. Then a man known by the name of "Cut Stumpy "came down to me and said, Jackson, I have got to find a buyer for that knocker—I am going to send Patsy Hearn down to you." I saw Patsy Hearn (Crossey) coming down the road. I said to him," Are you a buyer of a knacker." He said, "Yes." I showed it to him and asked £4, as I I was told to do. He said, "It is not worth £4 to me, I will give you £3 and I agreed. He then asked if there was anyone in the market knew me. I took him to the gatekeeper, who said he knew me and my brothers. Crossey then paid me £3. I went to the Pocock Arms, where Stumpy took 10s. I handed the £2 10s. to the gipsy and he gave me 5s. back out of it.

Cross-examined. I have been a good deal in the gipsy's company. He answers to the name of "Charlie Eyster"—I heard in Brixton that he bears that name. I know Stumpy by seeing him about the market and such places. I have not asked for him to be brought here. I did not ask the gipsy why he could not sell the horse him
self—it did not come into my mind that there was anything wrong.

Verdict,
Guilty.

Prisoner confessed to having been convicted at Clerkenwell Ses
sions on September 5, 1903, when he received three and a quarter years' penal servitude and three years police supervision for horse-stealing. Nine other convictions of horse and van stealing were proved, including 12 months, 18 months, 5 years, 5 years, 6 months, 3 1/2 years, 18 months, his last sentence being 3 £ years at North London Sessions for stealing a horse, van and contents.
The Common Serjeant said that this was a case in which the prisoner should have been dealt with as an habitual criminal under
the Prevention of Crimes Act, 1908, hut as he was not indicted in that way he could not he so dealt with.

Sentence,
Four years' penal servitude.

STOCKDALE, George (44, tinsmith) and
DUKELOW, Peter (27, fireman)
, both on August 19, 1909, stealing £1 10s., the moneys of
Henry Newcombe, the elder.
Mr. Eustace Fulton prosecuted.

HENRY NEWCOMBE . I am manager for my father, the licensee of the Earl of Derby public-house, London Road, West Ham. On August 19, 1909, at 4.30 p.m., the prisoners were in my bar there were several others there who left, and the prisoners were alone. I had occasion to leave the bar, and as I got outside the door, behind which was a Cox's till, I heard a sound and turned sharply back, when I saw Stockdale with stick produced in his hands. It is a fishing-rod and has sticky substance on a roll at the end of it. There was in the till £5 10s. in silver and a sovereign and a half-sovereign. The two gold coins were missing. I called out to my father, "Dad, they are taking money from the till by means of a stick,' and came into the bar, when the prisoners ran away. I gave chase. I saw Stock-dale throw the end part of the stick away while he was running. I caught him. He said, "All right guvnor, I have not got it with me, I have just thrown it away. "I gave him into custody. Dukelow escaped. On the following Saturday night I went to Plaistow Police Station, where I readily picked out Dukelow from a number of other men.

Cross-examined. I saw Stockdale with the stick in his hand and the money had disappeared. He dropped the coin in the bar outside the counter, picked it up and ran off. I did not recover the money. I did not see Dukelow pick any money up. He ran and threw the other part of the stick away. They had pulled the stick apart. Dukelow was not reading the paper when I left the bar.

Police-constable THOMAS GLADSTONE, 151 K, stationed at Plaistow. On August 15, at 5.15 p.m., I saw Stockdale detained in High Street, Plaistow, by the last witness, who said, "I want to give this man in charge for stealing 30s. from the till." I said to Stockdale, "Do you understand what he said?" Stockdale said, "Yes, sir; quite right, sir." I said, "I shall take you to the station on that charge." He said, "All right, sir." When charged at the station he said, "All right." I searched him, found 4d. in bronze and a seaman's dis
charge book. When the charge was read over he said, "All right, sir."

Detective-sergeant CHARLES HUTTON, K Division, stationed at Plaistow. On August 31, at 8.30 p.m., I saw Dukelow and told him I was a police officer and should take him into custody on suspicion of being concerned with a man named Stockdale in stealing 30s. from the bar of the "Earl of Derby "public-house at 5 p.m. on Thursday, the 19th inst. He made no reply. On the way to the station he said, "What time?" I told him, "5 p.m." At the station he was
Placed with nine other men and at once identified by Newcombe. He was then charged and made no reply. I found a seaman's discharge book on him.
Stockdale's statement before the magistrate. "I have nothing to say and no witnesses to call."
Dukelow's statement." I was with Stockdale. I have been out of work for a long time. As this is the first time I have ever done a thing like that I hope you will make it a bit light."
(Defence.)
George STOCKDALE (prisoner, not on oath). I have nothing to say.

Peter DUKELOW (prisoner, not on oath). I was waiting outside the plaistow Station at about three o'clock, when Stockdale asked me to come and have a drink. I never saw any stick. I was reading the paper the time. I saw Stockdale run out; I thought there was a row and I came out too.

Verdict (both),
Guilty.

Stockdale confessed to having been convicted at this court on De
cember 30, 1898, for stealing rabbits, receiving four months' hard Hour Several other short convictions for larceny and assault were proved. Dukelow had been summarily convicted in 1896.
BEFORE THE COMMON SERJEANT. (Tuesday, September 14.)

STERNE, William (20, shoemaker),
pleaded guilty of
on July 31, 1909, burglary in the dwelling-house of
Kate Dalley with intent to steal therein; on July 28, 1909, burglary in the dwelling-house of kate Dalley and stealing therein one bunch of keys, the goods of
Daisy Gurr.
In June, 1901, prisoner was convicted of sacrilege and sent to an industrial school until the age of 16

sentence,
Six months' hard labour.
BEFORE THE RECORDER.
(Wednesday, September 15.)

p.rs:
, breaking and entering the dwelling house of
William Rayner with intent to steal therein; attempting to break and enter the dwelling-house of
James Clarey with intent to steal therein.

div1.p: Mr. Bickmore prosecuted.

Police-constable GEORGE SHIELDS, 717 K. On August 2, about 5 p.m., I was off duty at my house, 28, Frederick Road. West Ham. Frederick Road overlooks 55 and 56, Invicta Road, which are flats occupied by a number of people. I saw prisoner and another man standing outside the house. Prisoner took a jemmy from his inside pocket. They walked to the door. The other man put the jimmy in the door and prisoner put his knee to the door, which flew open. Both entered and shut the door. I sent my wife to the police station for assistance and in the meantime kept the place under observation In a few minutes I saw prisoner and the other man go up the back-stairs and in a short time they came down again. I lost sight of them for a few minutes, and then saw prisoner go to No. 8, Randall Road. I caught hold of him and told him I was a police officer and should take him into custody for housebreaking in Invicta Road. He replied, "You have made a mistake." I took him to the police station, where, in reply to the charge, he said, "All right. "The other man darted past me and ran straight away.

KATE SHIELDS , wife of last witness. On August 2, about 4.15 p.m., I was in my front room, and through the window saw two men, one of them being prisoner, acting suspiciously. They walked to 56. Invicta Road, and the other man rang the bell twice; he then rapped on the letter-box twice. Then he stooped to look through the letter box; next I saw them trying to force the door. I called my husband and told him what I had seen. I saw prisoner hand the other man what looked like a piece of iron. My husband sent me to the police station on for assistance. I have no doubt whatever that prisoner was one of the men; as I was coming back I saw my husband taking him to the station.

WM. RATHER , carman. I am married and live at 55, Invicta Road I left my flat at 3.30 p.m. on August 2. it was then empty. I re
turned about 11.30 p.m. and found a police-constable standing at the corner. I found my place upside down. The latch 'had been broken off the door inside. On the outside of the door there were marks of an instrument having been used to force it open. In the bedroom all the drawers were turned over and the bed had been tampered with.

Police-sergeant WALTER BAXTER. 93 K, stationed at West Ham On August 2, at about 5 p.m., I was called to the premises, 55 and 56, Invicta Road. On examining the door of 56 I found an attempt had been made to, force the back door and this portion of a jimmy (produced)" was wedged in between the door post and the door.

Prisoner handed in a statement in which he said that on the day in question he was on his way home through Rendlesham Road, a thoroughfare parallel to Invicta Road, and when about five yards from the house which was broken into he saw two men rush out of the doorway and run down the street. He stopped to see what they were running for when the constable came up and said, "I want you for breaking into that house." He was taken to the station, where nothing was found on him. Taken before the magistrate,

remanded for eight days. A day or two afterwards a man named holder was arrested, and they were both examined on August 10. Both the officer and his wife swore that they watched the two men for 25 minutes and never lost sight of them, but Fielder brought six finesses to prove that he was at Southend on the day in question and he was discharged. If the officer and his wife were proved to be Mistaken as to one man, they might (he argued) be mistaken as to the other. He had lived in that part of West Ham for 36 years.
Mrs. SHIELDS, recalled, stated that there were very few people about in the afternoon of August 2. She identified Fielder from amongst a number of other men.

Police constable SHIELDS, recalled, said that when his wife called his attention to this matter he was resting. He identified Fielder and picked him out from ten others two days afterwards. The fate are self-contained and the back stairs lead to the upper flat. Fielder was six or seven yards off when witness arrested James. James gave no account of himself and no address at the station.
Prisoner JAMES. I told them I was living at a bootmakers in canning Town.

Verdict,
Not guilty.

p.rs:
; stealing one gallon of overproof run, the goods of the
Royal Mail Steam Packet Company, Limited, Mr. Bickmore prosecuted.

div1.p:
Dock-constable JOHN BREWER, Victoria Docks. On August 9, about 5 p.m., I was on duty in the dock, where-1 saw prisoner and kept him under observation. He is a docker, but never does any work. He was standing in the shed when I first taw him. When he saw me he took off his coat and pretended to be working with the other men, who were moving some full sacks. I went away to the top of the jetty and stood there a few minutes, still keeping observa
tion, and saw prisoner leave the shed carrying a jute bag in each hind. He then came on to the jetty, picked up some empty bottles and pat them into one of the bags, which he tied up. He had been carrying beer in for the dockers. I followed him to the gate, where stopped him. I told him I wanted to examine the bags, and asked him to untie them. He said, "You must untie them yourself." I stooped down to untie the bags. Prisoner then bolted away. I gave chase, but he was lost in the crowd of men leaving the docks, I have known him for 12 months or more. In one of the bags I found 27 empty bottles, and underneath them seven bottles of rum. I produce the bottles of rum, which have since been sealed by H. M. Custom House officers. I communicated with the Metropolitan Police and they arrested prisoner an hour and a half later. He was charged with being in possession of seven bottles of overproof rum belonging to the Royal Mail Steam Packet Company, and made no reply to the charge. To my knowledge rum is stored in the sheds along the quay This particular shed was open, as the men were working at the time. The bottles he was taking away were empty beer bottles. He had no business to take them.
To Prisoner. Beer is not supplied at the jetties without permissions. You had no permission to supply beer. I know several men who have permission.

To the Recorder. A shed is about 100 yards long and there was one man there to watch. Prisoner had not time to draw out the rum while I was watching him and it must have been all ready beforehand. Detective-constable WALTER LILLEY, Victoria Docks. On August 10, at 8 a.m., I went to "D" jetty. There were Rome casks of rum stored in "D "shed, about 200 puncheons. I examined the casks and found that one had had the tin removed from the shive and the shive had been taken out and so replaced that you could take it out with your finger and thumb. The shive is a kind of wooden bung; we have to use wood on account of the spirit. With the shive in that position the rum could easily be removed from the cask and transferred to a bottle. Behind the cask there is a gangway. I there found two empty bottles, which had contained beer. A good number of people have access to that shed and anybody knowing the condition of the casks and wishing to abstract the spirit would have the opportunity of filling up those bottles. I pointed out the puncheon to the Custom house officer on the station, and in my presence he drew a sample from the cask.

SAMUEL HECK , Custom House officer. I examined the cask men
tioned by last witness. Its full contents should have been 101 gallons I found a deficiency of six and a half gallons, but do not assume that six and a half gallons were taken out, it being customary to find even in a cask which has not been tampered with a vacuity representing a deficiency of three gallons or four gallons. The deficiency in this case was an unusual one, and I estimate that 2 1/2 gallons had been removed. The strength of the sample I took was 40. 4 deg. over proof. The spirit is from Demurrer a, and the average strength would be 36 deg or 40 deg. over proof. I found two of the bottles of rum produced by the police to be 39 deg. over proof and have no doubt the spirit came from the cask I examined. The value of the spirit in the seven bottles is 10s. 10d., and the duty upon it is £12s. 4d. £112s. 5d.

HARRY BOWMAN , assistant superintendent, Royal Mail Steam Packet Company. On August 4 we were discharging rum from the Catalonia at "D" jetty. Prisoner was not working for the company and bad no right to enter the premises or take rum. The rum in these bottles is the property of the company, who are the only people that discharge rum in the dock. The rum on being discharged would remain on the jetty a short time before it goes into bond.

Police-constable WILLIAM WALLER, 218, K. On August 9, about 7.30 p.m., I was on duty at the Victoria Dock and saw prisoner. In
formation had previously been received that a man named Compton was wanted for being in unlawful possession of bottles of rum I took him into custody; he said, "All right." When charged at the station he made no reply. To Prisoner. You were in drink when I arrested you.

prisoner said he took the beer into the shed in place of the man who usually did so, who was laid up, thinking he might as well earn a few shillings in that way as anybody else. The bottles of mm, he alleged, hid been put into the bag for spite by people who were jealous of him asking on the job.

Verdict,
Guilty of feloniously receiving. Several previous con
victions.

Sentence,
Eighteen months' hard labour.
BEFORE THE COMMON SERJEANT. (Wednesday, September 15.)

BRETT, James (23 carman), and
HEATH, Arthur (38, catameat vendor)
, both maliciously causing grievous bodily harm to
Minnie samovitz.
Mr. Allan Ramsay prosecuted; Mr. H. Warburton defended Brett, Mr. Gervais Rentoul defended Heath.

ABRAHAM SLAMOVITZ , 349, Queen's Road, Upton Park. On July 26, at 3 p.m., I was standing at my stall with my daughter Minnie, who was then 2✗ years old, when I heard a scream and saw her lying in the road on her face. I picked her up, when I saw prisoners driving away in a trap. My daughter's face was bleeding. After taking her to a doctor I took her to the London Hospital, where she was examined. There were no bones broken. She was in bed for three weeks and is still suffering from nervous attacks. There were a number of people in the road screaming.

Cross-examined. I did not see the accident. The two prisoners were charged at the police court—Brett had a month's imprisonment and Heath was fined. I have taken civil proceedings through a society the solicitor has written demanding damages. There was not such traffic in the road.
Re-examined. Prisoners were convicted at East Ham Police Court of being drunk in charge of a vehicle.

JOHN PACKER , M. B., 336, Queen's Road, Upton Park. On July 26, at 3 p.m., I examined the child Minnie. She was in a condition of shock and moaning; there were no broken bones or bruises—there was an abrasion across the face, apparently caused by the face rubbing against the road or the wheel. I attended her until August 4. She complained of pain in the back and was suffering from shock to the servous system. The injury to the face was quite superficial. I was informed that she starts up in her sleep.

ANNIE BAUM , 341, Queen's Road, Upton Park. On July 26 I saw the child lying in the road beneath the wheels of the cart. The two Prisoners were in the cart—they drove away. A great many people were shouting. I think Brett was driving.
Cross-examined. I did not notice Heath trying to stop the cart—it was going very quickly.

RAY MARKS , 260, Queens Road, Upton Park, wife of David Marks On July 26, at 3.5 p.m., I was walking home in Queens Road when I saw a cart and horse galloping along zig-zagging from side to side of the road. The horse knocked the child down. I screamed and shouted to stop the men but no notice was taken. I assisted the father to take the child to the doctor.
Cross-examined by Mr. Rentoul. The men tried to get out of the way of the child. I saw two men in the cart, but I did not see what they were doing.
Re-examined. The men made no effort to stop—they drove right away. One man 'held the whip and the other the reins.

BEN FILDMAN , 337, Queen's Road, cycle maker. On July 26, at 3 p.m., I saw a man and a boy running and shouting after a light spring cart in which Brett was driving, Heath sitting beside him They were driving eight to ten miles an hour on the near side. I then saw the child lying in the road. I holloaed out to them to stop, jumped on to a bicycle which was standing there and rode after them about 1 £ miles. Heath seemed to be trying to get Brett to stop, but the cart seemed to increase its pace. I spoke to a Constable, who took my bicycle and rode after them. There was no other traffic in the road, but with the stalls all along one side they could not see anyone very well who stepped out from a stall.

Police-constable JOHN GOWING, 640 K. On July 26, at about 3.20, I was in Katharine Road, East Ham, when I saw a pony and trap containing the two prisoners. Brett was holding the reins. Heath sitting on the offside had the whip in his hand whipping the pony, which was galloping full speed. Fildman spoke to me. I mounted his bicycle and followed the cart through Forest Road. blowing my whistle at intervals. As I did so Heath kept looking round at me and urging the pony. I followed them about four miles to Fernside, Beckton, when Sergeant Gale also took up the chase I on a bicycle, and we succeeded in stopping them. The pony was very much exhausted, bleeding from the flanks, the blood running down its hind legs. Its hind shoes were worn and the hoofs broken The prisoners were taken to East Ham Police Station, Brett was charged with being drunk in charge of a vehicle, Heath with being drunk and concerned with Brett in driving to the common danger Brett was very drunk. Heath was not so drunk, but very much excited—he knew what he was doing; he was in liquor but not so badly as Brett. I was informed of the present charge and inter viewed the father, but the accident was in West Ham another juris
diction, where they were charged with the offence.

Cross-examined by Mr. Rentoul. Heath was not trying to get Brett to pull up; he was urging the pony on and lashing it cruelly The reins were taken from Brett and the whip from Heath. Heath was not so drunk but that he knew what he was doing he was very much excited. Brett was very drunk.

Sergeant SAMUEL GALE, 110 K. On July 26, at about 3.15 p.m., I was returning to East Ham Police Station, when I beard cries and saw the prisoners seated in a pony trap driving at an excessive pace. I gave chase on my bicycle, overtook them at Cyprus Place, New Beckton. and took them into custody for being drunk and furiously driving. I took them to the station. Brett was charged with being drunk in charge of the pony and cart; both with being concerned in furiously driving the pony. Between 4 and 5 p.m. I learnt that a child had been knocked down. I saw the prisoners again and said, I as going to charge you with causing grievous bodily harm to Minnie Slamovitz at about 3 p.m. in Queen's Road." They were then charged and made no reply. It was found the other charge was in west Ham, and they were recharged at West Ham Police Court.
(Defence.)

ALBERT HENRY HEATH (prisoner, on oath). I live at 67, Eastbourne Road, West Ham, and am a catsmeat man. On July 26, at 3 p.m., I was in Whitechapel, coming home from market, when I met Brett in the trap, which belongs to his uncle, and came home with him, we had one or two drinks and Brett had a row with a publican. I got him out into the trap and came with him to see him home. As we cane down Queen's Road the child ran across the road, ran back, and then dashed right into the pony. The pony shied, the little child was knocked down, the pony bolted, and it was some time before Brett could control him. After we had got some distance I heard a police
man whistle. Both before and after I tried to stop the pony. At the up of the road the pony eased a bit, but Brett, being drunk and very excited, paid no attention and drove on. I tried to get the reins from him and got the whip away from him, but could not get him to stop. The police then chased us. I put the whip down in the cart and tried a got hold of the reins. I did not whip the horse at all. I tried my but to stop thepony. The Common Serjeant directed that the Jury should acquit the prisoners of intentional assault and causing grievous bodily harm, and put the question whether they caused injury by wanton or furious driving, by wilful misconduct or wilful neglect.

Verdict (both),
Guilty on the third count; not guilty on the first.
and second counts.

Sentence: Brett,
Three weeks' imprisonment, second division.

Heath,
one month's imprisonment, second division.
BEFORE THE RECORDER.
(Thursday, September 16.)

p.rs:
, maliciously throwing a certain corrosive fluid called carbolic acid at
George William Cole, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

div1.p: Mr. Bickmore prosecuted; Mr. Warburton defended. WILLIAM GEORGE COLE, 76, Forest Street, Forest Gate, carman. I have lived next door to prisoner with my parents twelve months; he was there when we came. There is a wooden fence dividing the two. gardens. When I came home to my dinner on Sunday, August 15. mother stood in the kitchen crying. I went into the back garden. and standing on a chair told prisoner if he did not stop calling my mother filthy names I should put a stop to it. He had a jug in his hand and threw the contents into my face, saying, "Take that you bastard." I was seen by a doctor and my father sent fur the police. I was not seriously injured.

Cross-examined. I am not employed by the local Council. I cannot get carbolic acid from the Council. Mr. Read's wife gave my wife half a pail full of carbolic acid to put down the sink. My father offered bait of it back, but Mrs. Read said she had plenty of it indoors. I was not drunk on this afternoon. I was at a public house from quarter past two till closing time. I did not call prisoner's wife offensive names. I did not say, "Fetch your f—g husband; I will blind him," or anything like that. I had not a broomstick in my hand when I was standing on the chair. The carbolic, acid was not accidentally knocked over. I do not know it was prisoner who went to fetch the policeman. I do not recollect anything after the stuff was thrown over me until 10 o'clock at night Re-examined. I was in the public-house three-quarters of an hour and had five or six drinks. My mother used the carbolic acid given her by the prisoner to put down the drains.

It appearing that the Grand Jury had ignored the graver counts, acting on the advice of counsel, prisoner
pleaded guilty, and was
released on his own recognisances in £20 to come up for judgment if called upon.

HIGGINS, Henry (45, labourer),
pleaded guilty of,
on August 6, 1909, stealing one purse containing £3 2s., the goods and moneys of
Emma Gall.

Mr. B. MOORE, who appeared to prosecute, said prisoner was seen by a lady, living two doors away from prosecutrix's house, to put his hand through the open window and take something from it. She gave notice to the police and prisoner was pursued and found in a public-house. On the way to the station he confessed.
Numerous convictions were proved, three months' imprisonment being the longest sentence.

Sentence,
Four months' hard labour.
